comments.author: @Avi_0818
comments.text:
The demise of ancient Egypt ?
The Ancient Egyptian Empire was one of the oldest and longest ruling empires in history. The empire lasted over 3,000 years. During that time the empire rose and fell as power shifted from one clan to the next and the occasional invasion from neighboring empires. However, history shows that even the mightiest empires can fall and after 1,100 BC, Egypt went into decline. There were several reasons for this including a loss of military power, lack of natural resources, and political conflicts.
The reigns of the last great pharaohs Ramses II and Ramses III 1,189 BC to 1,077 BCE are identified by strength and ability to defend Egypt against invaders. However, it took manpower and resources to ward off these continual attacks and these defenses left the economy‚Äôs empire struggling.Egypt experienced a civil war and remained split between two regions. This left it endangered to further invasions and control from the Assyrians in 671 BCE, the Persians in 525 BCE and finally the Greeks in 332 BCE.
At the end of Egypt‚Äôs empire the climate became unreliable and unstable. The Egyptians relied on the water from the Nile floods to help their crops grow, but the Egyptian climate experiences roughly a hundred of years of dry spells and hundreds of years water became uncommon.
There were also periods of unusually cold weather that further stressed the crops and led to a dramatic decrease in harvests. Crops were also destroyed by strong and unpredictable flooding of the Nile. With little to no food or surplus for long periods of time, hunger and famine spread.
Economic and political unrest also led to the weakening of the Ancient Egyptian empire. There were huge inequalities in the distribution of wealth among the elites and the rest of the population. Many people began to distrust the government and religious authority. The continuous wars created huge expenses and weakened the economic power of the Pharaoh.
Christianity began to spread through Egypt and brought the adoption of the alphabet replacing hieroglyphics and creating major changes in Egyptian culture. Many ancient practices such as mummification ended

comments.text: Maybe they were advanced‚Ä¶maybe not. If they were, it begs the question of why they were constructing with primitive materials. Many people find it profound that pyramids are found around the world, but that‚Äôs like finding philosophical meaning in most modern structures around the world are square or rectangular. The reason is the architectural stability inherent in the shape. Pyramids are found around the world because of the very primitiveness of the societies building them. Without technologies like advanced metallurgy, the pyramidal shape provides the large base with narrow tip which allowed them to reach heights otherwise unachievable without the materials which exist today with which we build skyscrapers in a straight path upwards. Yet, even with the largest bases, pyramids are still limited to a relative shortness. The pyramidal shape, if anything, is the proof of the primitive society. What is likeliest is that the societies involved had a technology that would seem advanced to us but was possible then that enabled them to move/fashion these stones in ways we‚Äôve yet to think of.

comments.text:
they moved and cut them with sound: instead of vibrating tool like we do, they vibrated the stone with choral songs and big metal tuning forks. a stone vibrating with resonance is effectively 50% easier to move because surface friction is reduced drastically. they moved them up the wooden logs by vibrating the logs. if you vibrate a heavy stone on a wooden plank it would go down, slowly because vibration reduces friction, but if you push it from below at the same time - it would go up the logs easier. they broke them apart by drilling holes with sound-vibrating tools & sand-water solution and then they've stuck tuning forks inside, sending cracks like we do today with explosives. For moving heavy stones they also made holes for tuning forks so they can vibrate the stone during the move, reducing friction. That's also how leedskalnin built coral castle.

Ancient Egyptians or Kemet people used sound like we use electricity today. They have generated, transferred and transformed it into mechanical energy.
